 Have some egg on your face, Trebor:
 
 THE SUN DARKENED AT NOON
 
 Circa 750 B.C.
 
 According to Amos 1:1, Amos prophesied during the reigns of Uzziah, king of Judah (767-739 B.C.), and Jeroboam, king of Israel (782-753 B.C.). The name "Amos" is derived from the Hebrew term meaning, "lift a burden," or "burden-bearer" (note Isaiah 9:4, speaking of the coming Messiah as one who would carry our burdens, and also Matthew 11:28). His calling by God was to foretell of pending judgments upon a number of surrounding nations, and particularly of a coming judgment upon Israel. As is common with other Biblical prophets, along with the promise of impending judgment, God also gave Amos a glimpse of events that would soon occur in the life of the coming Messiah, though the significance of what was prophesied may or may not have been made known to Amos. And so it is in the Old Testament book of Amos that we find a prophecy that for many centuries was looked upon with wonder and curiosity:
 
 "'In that day,' declares the Sovereign Lord, 'I will make the sun go down at noon and darken the earth in broad daylight....I will make that time like mourning for an only son, and the end of it like a bitter day.'" (Amos 8:9-10)
 
 It probably wasn't until the day of the crucifixion of Jesus Christ in 32 A.D. that the prophecy of Amos took on clarity and meaning, for in Matthew 27:45 Jesus had just been nailed to the cross when the Bible records:
 
 "From the sixth hour until the ninth hour darkness came over all the land."
 
 Just as the "Star of Bethlehem" marked the birth of Christ, so now God brought forth another celestial miracle to pronounce His death. This prophecy is one of those that is beyond the control of mortal man, and as such it dispels the theory that Christ could have manipulated events so as to make it appear that He was the Messiah. But is there any evidence that this really occurred? Did the sun go dark at noonday? In his book, Evidence That Demands a Verdict (Volume 1, pages 81-87), Josh McDowell provides the following historical evidence that what took place at Calvary was more that just fanciful mythology:
 
 Concerning the Samaritan-born historian Thallus, circa 52 A.D: (The writings of Thallus no longer exist, yet were alluded to by the historian Julius Africanus, as follows): "Thallus, in the third book of his histories, explains away this darkness as an eclipse of the sun - unreasonably, as it seems to me - unreasonably, of course, because a solar eclipse could not take place at the time of a full moon, and it was at the season of the Paschal full moon that Christ died."
 
 Likewise, Africanus wrote concerning the writings of another first century historian by the name of Phlegon: "....during the time of Tiberius Caesar an eclipse of the sun occurred during the full moon." 
 
 Phlegon is also mentioned by the historian Origen in his work, "Contra Celsum," book 2, sections 14, 39, and 59: "Phlegon mentioned the eclipse that took place during the crucifixion of the Lord Christ....and this is shown by the historical account itself of Tiberius Caesar." Apparently at one time there were historical accounts of the strange darkness that came over the land that were kept in the official archives of Tiberius Caesar, though they are likely lost to history.
 
 Finally, the 2nd century Roman born jurist and theologian Tertullian referred to a Roman archives report of an "unexplained darkness that took place during the reign of Tiberius Caesar, as can be seen in the archives of Pontius Pilate."
 
 The darkness spoken of in the book of Matthew occurred between noon and three P.M. in the afternoon (from the sixth to the ninth hours, as the Jews were noted as referring to the sixth and the ninth hours of daylight). Note that a solar eclipse will take less than an hour to complete, and a total solar eclipse lasts just a few minutes. This, coupled with the fact that a solar eclipse cannot occur during a full moon (the moon would be on the 'other' side of the earth), provides further evidence that what occurred was something other than an eclipse of the sun. Just what it was no one can say for sure, just that from recorded historical sources there was a strange darkness during the time of the crucifixion of Jesus Christ. From God's perspective, it surely was a time of mourning for His only begotten son. 
 
 Jesus once said, "I am the light of the world." So it shouldn't be surprising that during his death there might be a time of darkness over the land. 
 
 
 REFERENCE: McDowell, Josh. Evidence That Demands A Verdict (Vol. 1). Thomas Nelson Publishers. Nashville. 1972.

A bit about the darkness legend.
 
 
 
 
John makes no mention of any such events, nor does Paul or any other New Testament author. Such a story has obvious mythic overtones and can easily be doubted. That a solar eclipse should mark the death of a king was common lore among Greeks and other Mediterranean peoples (Herodotus 7.37, Plutarch Pelopidas 31.3 and Aemilius Paulus 17.7-11, Dio Cassius 55.29.3, John Lydus De Ostentis 70.a), and that such events corresponded with earthquakes was also a scientific superstition (Aristotle Meteorology 367.b.2, Pliny Natural History 2.195, Virgil Georgics 2.47.478-80). It was also typical to assimilate eclipses to major historic events, even when they did not originally correspond, or to invent eclipses for this purpose (Préaux claims to have counted 200 examples in extant literature; Boeuffle and Newton have also remarked on this tendency). The gospel stories also make a solar eclipse impossible: the crucifixion passover happened during a full moon, and the darkness supposedly lasted three hours (indeed, Julius Africanus claimed it covered the whole world). Such an impossible event would not fail to be recorded in the works of Seneca, Pliny, Josephus or other historians, yet it is not mentioned anywhere else outside of Christian rhetoric ...
 (http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/richard_carrier/thallus.html)
 

 
 
 
 Most scholars have assumed that Africanus is here quoting Phlegon, too, as a witness to the darkness story--although we know for a fact that Phlegon wrote in the 140's AD, and was fond of fantastic stories, so it would not be surprising to find him borrowing this one from Christian literature. But Martin Routh noticed some telling details: the sentence mentioning Phlegon is grammatically and logically out of place.
 
 In Greek, new sentences are marked by certain special words, usually left untranslated, such as MEN or DE or OUN, etc. The Phlegon sentence is not marked. That is like not leaving a period at the end of the preceding sentence. Also, Africanus has just finished attacking Thallus' idea of a solar eclipse, yet here cites Phlegon favorably, who calls it the same exact thing. Moreover, the flow of thought is broken by this sentence. Africanus has begun a rhetorical argument with the phrase "let it be so," which is otherwise interrupted by interjecting a historical note about Phlegon. Remove that sentence (and the added "Clearly this is our eclipse!") and we have a continuous stream of thought that makes more sense. The Phlegon sentence, for all of these reasons, does not belong here.
 (http://www.infidels.org/library/modern/richard_carrier/thallus.html)

 Ah, a spiky subject indeed (in many ways). I am no member of Opus Dei, but I have read up on it, and, being Catholic, have decided to try to understand why an institution so grossly attacked for crimes and practises so brutal as the ones cited has been accepted fully as part of the Church. 
 
 Now, the concept of self-mortification has been the object of grotesque propaganda, and of myopic analysis. First of all, self-mortification is a practise preached by Opus Dei, but it is much wider and profound than a simply harming oneself. Self-mortification is a doctrine through which a person decides to inconvenience or trouble himself with unnecessary burdens, and offer that extra "suffering" to God as sacrifice. So, in a way, instead of offering gold or animals, we offer ourselves, although in a very graphic manner. So, depending on your attitude and personality, there will be different kinds of self-mortification for different people. For example, if it is difficult for you to wake up in morning, your self-mortification could be to try to sit up immediately when the alarm goes off (regardless of what you have to do later), and then offer that extra effort as sacrifice to God. Or, for instance, if you like long hot showers, you could try, from time to time, to shower for less time and in slightly cooler water, etc. The doctrine of Opus Dei states that, after a myriad of these small sacrifices every day, one strengthens the will to do what reason commands, and in so doing becomes ever more virtuous. As you begin to dominate the initial sacrifices, you may want to go a step further, and, for example, force yourself to become a volunteer at a hospital or orphanage, even though you have to tighten your schedule, or you hate volunteering. Then, you can go up and force yourself to go to mass everyday, confess more frequently (the once a week standard is not general, you set your own goals, with the assistance of a "spiritual guide" that you find within Opus Dei). Of course, your self-mortification must never interfere with your primary responsibilities, which are your most important offering to God. This is way many people are members of Opus Dei and it is not known: they are regular laypeople that work and study, and they try to do it the best they can, as well as offering these little sacrifices. The cilice and the flagellation are very high and (I must say) grotesque forms of self-mortification, they are of course not compulsory, but they do denote a profound commitment: you can offer your own flesh to God, as he did to us. 
 
 Now, doubtless you will have something to say here, Simone.

 quote mining is taking a quote out of context. The term 'quote mining' has been used to you many times.
 
 I am sorry you can't understand the simpliist things.

But what's interesting is subjective "moral" frameworks like yours, which change almost daily in various parts of the world.

 
 Evolutionary psychology / sociobiology provides a perfectly sound objective framework for the existence of moral codes in human societies. In pre-scientific times, representing the prevailing morality as the commandments of an almighty diety was no doubt a very effective way of rationalising and enfocing it.
 
 It is the nature of all moral codes that they change over time, with the circumstances of the society whose interests they serve - viz. your celebrated 'new covenant', for all your protestations that it did not cover moral issues. Slavery and the torture of heretics were once considered morally acceptable by christians; divorce and re-marriage were not. This malleability is exactly what we would expect of an evolved, adaptive system, but squares poorly with the notion of the infallible commandments of an all-knowing deity.
 
 
If there's no "god", then you can butcher anyone you want; engage in bestiality, and any other morally reprehensible sin without one's conscience being impinged, because one person's framework is just as legitimate as anyone else's.

 
 This is the feeblest of straw men. Human societies everywhere and at all times have had moral codes regulating such matters, irrespective of their belief or not in a rule-giving deity.

If there's no "god", then you can butcher anyone you want; engage in bestiality, and any other morally reprehensible sin without one's conscience being impinged, because one person's framework is just as legitimate as anyone else's.

 
 Is that the only thing that stops you from committing those acts ?
 
 So for instance if it was found out there was no God then the first thing you would do is find some farm yard animals to fornicate with ?
 
 I think I have mentioned before in another thread that belief in a God does not necessarily makes someone a moral person. Those morals that have been passed down by God allowed people to stone adulterers, was the basis for the crusades, was the the basis for the Inquisition and many other immoral acts. Even those God given morals have changed, your moral framework is just as subjective as ours. 
 
 I am unsure how a believer in God can claim moral superiority if you take History and even some current affairs into account.
 
 Another thing if those morals where handed down by God then why are those morals so varied between different believers in a deity ?

Big Bear, sorry to turn the discussion back to The Da Vinci Code, but didn't the last scenes take place in Scotland?
 
 And, isn't there an old church in Scotland that contains one or more of Dan Brown's artsy clues to his fictionalized theories? I think the dude is an art historian or something of that ilk--and the book kind of centers on visual clues, so to speak.

Big Bear, sorry to turn the discussion back to The Da Vinci Code, but didn't the last scenes take place in Scotland?
 
 And, isn't there an old church in Scotland that contains one or more of Dan Brown's artsy clues to his fictionalized theories? I think the dude is an art historian or something of that ilk--and the book kind of centers on visual clues, so to speak.

 
 To actually post on Topic that just feels plain weird. :)
 
 http://www.rosslynchapel.org.uk/
 
 Yes the last scenes are set in a place called Rosslyn Chapel, a lovely little place. If you ever come over to Scotland I would suggest that you take a little visit to the Chapel. The locals are making a fortune out of tourism so at least some Dan Brown's writings where useful.
Big Bear, thanks for the cool link!

Slavery and the torture of heretics were once considered morally acceptable by christians;

 
 What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery and torture? Where's your Scriptural basis for these claims?
 
 
 Human societies everywhere and at all times have had moral codes regulating such matters, irrespective of their belief or not in a rule-giving deity.

 
 Moral compared to man's ideas or God's objective standards? 
 
 Any moral code that is not based on God's Word, as clarified by Jesus and the New Testament writers, is hardly moral in God's eyes, or in the eyes of his believers.

What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery and torture? Where's your Scriptural basis for these claims?

 
 Did you actually read the post you were responding to?
 
 
Slavery and the torture of heretics were once considered morally acceptable by christians

 
 Lots of pious believers have owned slaves; some traded in them. The church once taught that heretics had to be tortured and burned for their own salvation.
 
 You will now pull the no-true-Scotsman fallacy to demonstrate to your own satisfaction that the slavers and torturers were not True Christians. This does not affect my argument, which addressed the malleable nature of all moral codes. In the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the bible-sanctioned morality of contemporary christians happily encompassed behaviours modern christians would call barbaric. 
 
 
Moral compared to man's ideas or God's objective standards? Any moral code that is not based on God's Word, as clarified by Jesus and the New Testament writers, is hardly moral in God's eyes, or in the eyes of his believers.

 
 You have shifted your ground. I was responding to your assertion that the only alternative to your god's imposed morality was no morality at all: 
 
 
If there's no "god", then you can butcher anyone you want; engage in bestiality, and any other morally reprehensible sin without one's conscience being impinged...

 
 This is palpably untrue. A tribal society that has never heard of your god still has a moral code; whether or not you regard it as valid is immaterial.

Did you actually read the post you were responding to?
 Lots of pious believers have owned slaves; some traded in them. The church once taught that heretics had to be tortured and burned for their own salvation.

 
 The way you presented that makes it look like all Christians and probably Christ himself taught that. 
 
 
You will now pull the no-true-Scotsman fallacy to demonstrate to your own satisfaction that the slavers and torturers were not True Christians.

 
 I stand by what I said: "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery and torture? Where's your Scriptural basis for these claims?
 
 
 This does not affect my argument, which addressed the malleable nature of all moral codes. In the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, the bible-sanctioned morality of contemporary christians happily encompassed behaviours modern christians would call barbaric.

 
 Again, "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think justifies barbaric behavior? 
 
 
 You have shifted your ground. I was responding to your assertion that the only alternative to your god's imposed morality was no morality at all: 

 
 That wasn't my assertion. I said, "Any moral code that is not based on God's Word, as clarified by Jesus and the New Testament writers, is hardly moral in God's eyes, or in the eyes of his believers."
 
 
A tribal society that has never heard of your god still has a moral code; whether or not you regard it as valid is immaterial.

 
 Again, "moral" in who's eyes, man's or God's?

Again, "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think justifies barbaric behavior?

 
 I'm not sure whether we're seeing here your talent for evasion or for missing the point. I suppose it might be both. I repeat: good, pious christians in the Middle Ages and later had a moral code that they believed was consistent with biblical teachings, but which encompassed behaviours modern christians would call barbaric. The plasticity of morality is demonstrable: it bends to suit the circumstances of the age.
 
 You have plucked one well-known quote from the bible. Those who burned witches could pluck out Exodus 22:18 just as easily. That's the beauty of the bible: mine it diligently enough, and you'll find a justification for virtually anything.
 
 
That wasn't my assertion. I said, "Any moral code that is not based on God's Word, as clarified by Jesus and the New Testament writers, is hardly moral in God's eyes, or in the eyes of his believers."

 
 The assertion in question:
 
 
Originally Posted by Easyrider
 If there's no "god", then you can butcher anyone you want; engage in bestiality, and any other morally reprehensible sin without one's conscience being impinged...

 
 Do you have a Master's in evasion?
 
 
Again, "moral" in who's eyes, man's or God's?

 
 Another masterly missing of the point. You may have noticed from past posts that I do not believe this god thing exists. The point is that whether it does or not, human societies generate perfectly functional moral codes of their own.

I stand by what I said: "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery and torture? Where's your Scriptural basis for these claims?
 

 
 "Your male and female slaves are to come from the nations around you; from them you may buy slaves." Leviticus 25:44 
 
 Also "Slaves, in all things obey those who are your masters on earth, not with external service, as those who merely please men, but with sincerity of heart, fearing the Lord." Col 3:22
 
 The bible doesn't endorse torture, it tells us to treat slaves with care, but nonetheless it does not say that slavery is evil.

I stand by what I said: "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery and torture? Where's your Scriptural basis for these claims?
 

 
 "Your male and female slaves are to come from the nations around you; from them you may buy slaves." Leviticus 25:44 
 
 Also "Slaves, in all things obey those who are your masters on earth, not with external service, as those who merely please men, but with sincerity of heart, fearing the Lord." Col 3:24
 
 The bible doesn't endorse tortue, it tells us to treat slaves with care, but nonetheless it does not say that slavery is evil.

"Your male and female slaves are to come from the nations around you; from them you may buy slaves." Leviticus 25:44 
 
 Also "Slaves, in all things obey those who are your masters on earth, not with external service, as those who merely please men, but with sincerity of heart, fearing the Lord." Col 3:24
 
 The bible doesn't endorse tortue, it tells us to treat slaves with care, but nonetheless it does not say that slavery is evil.

 
 You need to know that much of slavery was voluntary in those days, where people got into debt and sold themselves as slaves to pay off their indebtedness. 
 
 Jeremiah 34:14ff - "Every seven years each of you must free any fellow Hebrews who have sold themselves to you. After they have served you for six years, you shall set them free." ..... But your ancestors did not obey me or pay any attention to me."
 
 In other cases, it was a judgment of God on corrupt nations for a time.
 
 But my argument remains, "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery?"

Jeremiah 34:14ff - "Every seven years each of you must free any fellow Hebrews who have sold themselves to you. After they have served you for six years, you shall set them free." ..... But your ancestors did not obey me or pay any attention to me."

 
 Foreigners were less lucky:
 
 
However, you may purchase male or female slaves from among the foreigners who live among you. You may also purchase the children of such resident foreigners, including those who have been born in your land. You may treat them as your property, passing them on to your children as a permanent inheritance. You may treat your slaves like this, but the people of Israel, your relatives, must never be treated this way. (Leviticus 25:44-46 NLT)

 
 
But my argument remains, "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery?"

 
 What is it about 'you may purchase male or female slaves ...' that you think does not?

But my argument remains, "What is it about "Love your neighbor as you love yourself" that you think endorses slavery?"

 
 If the bible both endorses and condemns slavery, that is a contradiction. if you accept that this is a contradiction, that's fine. If not, please tell me why it isn't a contradiction.

If the bible both endorses and condemns slavery, that is a contradiction. if you accept that this is a contradiction, that's fine. If not, please tell me why it isn't a contradiction.

 
 First, do you admit the Bible portrays the slavery that does exist in three main lights: 
 
 1. Voluntary servitude
 2. Judgment by God on corrupt nations / peoples
 3. Slavery unauthorized by God
 
 Apart from these, I welcome a fourth example from Scripture so I can add that to my knowledge base.

 Yes, I agree that the bible portrays that. I'd like to add that 2 and 3 are just as bad as each other, but continue your explanation anyway.
